author: {'steamid': '76561198162768792', 'num_games_owned': 1134, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1693365104}
review:
An oldie but a goodie. When I first picked it up, I was a little worried that it was going to be a spreadsheet game, balancing one set of numbers against another, mixmaxing the right formula to convince the AI to do what I wanted.

Luckily my fears were unfounded. There [i]are[/i] a lot of numbers, but you don't have to dive any deeper than you want to--while the AI races are simulated to a deep level, you only need the surface stats to see what's going on. And while a lot of the gameplay requires numbers to go up (your influence, interplanetary relations, planetary conditions, etc.), you have a wide variety of tools to affect those numbers: tactical space combat, treaty-making, influence-peddling, even long-term research/mining/construction contracts. It never felt like "I need to increase this number"--I was always [i]doing[/i] something.

The other thing I really liked about the game was how different the races were from each other. There were the warlords who only respond to bribes, blackmail, and duels to the death. Or the robotic capitalists that want to see the profit in every action. Secretive spymasters that get annoyed just from talking to you. Or the hive-mind that will only negotiate on matters concerned with its current priority, but is susceptible to irregular mood swings. It's a bustling solar system that truly has a life of its own. I could just watch the simulation play out if I wasn't so concerned with preventing them all from killing each other.

There's one caveat to my recommendation though: It is an old game and doesn't play well with some modern systems. It crashes fairly often on my laptop, though the autosaves mean I never lost [i]too[/i] much progress. I've also run into a bug that effectively froze time in my solar system, meaning I couldn't complete that game. Steam's two-hour refund window should be enough to see how well it plays, but do be aware that it is old and might do better on an older machine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971448038', 'num_games_owned': 998, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2795, 'last_played': 1675717483}
review:
It plays more like a Grand Strategy Lite rather than a 4X game. The objective is to form a federation of up to 8 different races, each with their own specialty and their innate biases against everyone else.

You try and build up your own influence with other races and help foster the races influence with each other. There are several ways of accomplishing this, by helping build up their economy and ship armadas, cooperative research, forming trade routes with each other, etc.. all the while trying to stop them from killing each other.

You can also do hostile actions against a race if you don't particularly like someone and want everyone to gang up on them.

The 2 DLCs gives you 3 different game modes you can try.

Betrayal mode is when you play as your own race and own planet, and try to take over all the other races. This plays more like a 4X game.

Invasion mode is where you and the other races have to defeat another new race that is stronger and technologically more advanced all the while trying to foster relations between the other races. This mode is probably the hardest one to accomplish.

The last mode is a tech race in the same format as the original federation mode, but winning is only possible by getting all the techs before anyone else. This mode isn't as difficult but it just takes a long time to accomplish with a lot of tech to research.

The 2nd part of the game is a top down turn based bullet hell ship combat, similar to Space Rangers HD (a game I think is vastly overlooked), which occurs when destroying pirate base, attacking other race directly, doing missions that pops up, etc..

The tutorial is actually pretty good in that it hides some of the features of the game, and slowly introducing them one by one. You will probably want to watch a lets play video first to see if this game would interest you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963922976', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1546003235}
review:
The Last Federation.

A very unique game, like pretty much every game by Arcen Games.

This is a combination of a 4X game and a Tactical Action Combat game where you control one ship. How does that work? Well, you are in a 4X game, but you are one single alien with a really powerful ship. The 4X game is the world in which you inhabit, but you do not actually control any of the Civs. To put it another way, you are in a simulated 4X game world, and you are one quite powerful individual who seeks to influence this world. 

What happened is that you were part of an ancient and super powerful Civ. This Civ held universal sway, controlling and ruling other smaller Civs. But they were all destroyed. You are the last survivor of this Civ. You have one ship left, so you are very powerful, but you are only one person. So you have a much out-sized impact on galactic events for one person, however, destroying a whole Civ army by yourself is probably out of the question.

So you watch and wait while the many civs that currently exist, but which are not spacefaring, learn spaceflight and join the galactic community. This waiting period is short, and you can raise any Civ you wish to spaceflight immediately. However, when a civ is space-faring, they become aware of all the other Civs that exist but not at that tech level, and they place their own satellites their planets to watch. So whenever you fly to a planet to lift a Civ, you have increasingly difficult time sneaking through the array of satellites above a planet, because the more people that are space-faring, the more satellites to avoid. This feeds one of the most important mechanics, which is how much each Civ likes you. A Civ will get a boost to how much they like you if you raise them to space. However, every other Civ that detects your action will dislike you somewhat for this act. And it is this balance of actions that drives the experience.

Every Civ likes themselves, so helping them makes them like you. But every Civ fears the other Civs, so your actions to help one Civ will make others fear you and dislike you. This seems impossible to manage. However, Civs will form bonds with other Civs. So if two Civs like each other, then helping one makes the other one like you as well. This is why getting Civs working together is so important, because your actions are liked by more people. But this process is difficult. 

Every Civ has their own political system. One may be essentially a democracy with favours as currency, but another might be a hive mind with one insect leader. The currency of favour for one Civ is completely useless for every other Civ. They have very different desires and buffs and debuffs. However, they all use roughly the same technology.

You may worry about how to unite everyone into a single federation. That is actually hard, and not required. You can kill or save whoever you want. You can choose what your goal is, and decide whether you were successful or not in dealing with all the various randomly generated events.

The set of actions available to you is mind boggling. It is very vast, but they are all labelled to show you the actual benefit you will get to important things like how much every Civ will like or dislike you for an action. However, some actions have additional benefits and it will take a while to understand those things. It is also the case that there may be multiple pages of actions available. As in, you cannot just open the interaction page for a civ and see everything there. There are multiple pages of different possible actions. The categories make sense, but until you get a real hang of what you can do, it is possible there will be whole sets of actions available that you didn’t even know existed. Time moves forward, but you can speed or slow or stop it as much as you like.

I said there was combat, but I haven’t talked about it yet. Remember how I talked about satellites surrounding planets and sneaking past them? This is one of the things you actually perform via the tactical action turn based combat. I say turn based, but it is a weird hybrid, where it is real time divided into bits. You are in an overhead view, and control your one ship. There will be many other ships and structures and turrets and other things. This is a type of bullet hell game, but without reflexes. Time is divided into maybe one or two second chunks. For each chunk, you control how you move and where you shoot, and with which gun. You also control where your energy for the turn goes. It can be divided between Gun power, movement power, and shield power. There is an absolute amount of power, so you choose priority levels. Gun power increases are obvious. Movement power increases both how far you can move for the turn, but also how tightly you can maneuver, which is useful for dodging bullets. Shield power increases shield regen. Guns are quite different, and you also have some special abilities. You may wonder whether frozen time makes it impossible to tell where bullets are moving, but the bullets are shaped so that you can tell where they are moving even when frozen. I don’t remember ever being hit by something I didn’t know was going to be where it ended up being. You can get in combat quite a bit, not only through choice, but through assassins trying to kill you. You cannot die and lose the game, but dying means you spend time regenerating to fully working again, which means lost time to influence the universe. Time will move forward and you have no control over what happens. 

The Last Federation is very unique. It allows you to do things you would never have thought possible. But that variety can be both difficult to understand, and possibly not interesting to do. Your interaction with the universe is mostly like a 4X. So if you are routinely use your imagination to turn number representations into real felt experiences, then this will be more acceptable. However, even though you have a lot of choices, its not like you are managing completely different mechanics systems. You are largely dealing with a limited set of mechanics with a lot of apparent variety, but not really in that you are picking between different options that largely move the same meters different amounts, and choosing between those things. But also dealing with individual complicated political systems that will take quite a bit to understand. There are also a lot of possible outcomes, because of the inter-relations of many unique groups.

 The game has changed a lot over the years. When I first played it when it came out, I played for something like 10 hours without resolving a single play through. The second time, years later, I played for three or four hours and completed a run, so there are massive changes that have happened over the years. 

The Last Federation is very novel, but your interactions can be somewhat obscure, and might not be as varied as you may think at the start. But there is a lot to inspire the imagination. I recommend it, but it is very weird.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017126637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1751, 'last_played': 1668240464}
review:
You play as an ancient alien survivor who can influence the fate of an alien galaxy. You have many ways to manipulate the races and it can be fun to experiment and behave like a good (or bad) super galactic independent diplomat. 
I'm not all that keen on the battles though. The combat is very different than the strategy map. In the map you play more like a leader, influencing and manipulating subtly (or not) but in the battle you're right in the mixer, piloting your lone ship in a top down 2D turn-based tactical, bullet-hell space shooter. These two very different modes are in a awkward juxtaposition. I suspect most people will have a clear preference for one mode only, and try to avoid the other.   

Battle difficulty is dependant on game year and what your trying to do, so ranges all the way from 'Can't lose on purpose' to 'Completely impossible'. Different weapons seem redundant, and there are obviously better weapons so you'll never use some weapons once you've tried them. 

It has a moderate learning curve and will seem more complicated than it actually is. Not a great tutorial but serviceable although many concepts are not explained well or at all. Can be a little frustrating and sometimes feels a bit tedious. Hasn't got great replay value.
Information overload. Events are happening all the time and you kinda feel you need to be aware of all of them so it can feel overwhelming at times, and there is a fair bit of reading required to keep up.

The grand strategy game is fairly interesting and very original, if a little tedious, but I would 
 mostly recommend it for being something different. The battles aren't bad they are just a bit repetitive and auto-resolve doesn't work very well sometimes. The DLC adds some modes that flesh out the game a little but come with their own frustrations. Overall I'd say 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116551445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1664115610}
review:
This is a weird one, and it's weird in ways that make it hard to review. There's a little less agency over the events of the game than I usually like, but it *is* a game about being a behind-the-scenes influence peddler, so that's something I should have expected. It's a lot more text based then I feel like the advertisements made it seem, but that's not necessarily a bad thing if it's well written (I found it pretty flat). The turn-based bullet-heck space combat system was weird and felt a bit unpolished to me, but I also wouldn't mind playing a game where that mechanic featured more prominently than this game. The one thing that I think they did objectively poorly was in the way you interact with the various races. Why they all have their own individual governments and behind the scenes personalities, the options I had in how I interacted with them, and how they interacted with me felt pretty much the same between all of them. I would have appreciated a lot more flavor in that regard, but it's also possible that they get more distinct as the game progresses and I just didn't have the patience to get to that point. It was pretty slow, but also it's pretty complex, so it needed to be slow in the beginning to introduce all the mechanics and options.

I didn't like it, but I really don't know if that means you won't.

review: One of my all time favorite hidden gem games. Play as a superpowerful alien, the last of of his species, and manipulate all the other alien species into forming a federation so that the atrocity that destroyed your species won't be repeated. I love the core gameplay because basically a big simulation is running as the aliens trade and treat and go to war with each other, keeping track of their economy and their fleets and technology. What you can do is come in and put your thumb on the scales, gifting species with research or helping them build up their fleet or solving their economic problems. You're basically a demigod, and come and go from planet to planet trying to earn the trust of the different species while keeping them from annihilating each other. Also, combat is turn-based bullet hell in case this game didn't sound different enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999561475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4658, 'last_played': 1638898732}
review:
Really different game.  The 4X basics are there  - research, planetary development, fleet building.  You don't engage in much of it directly though, instead you're influencing different races.  Not only that, but you're really working to get the various races to *not* exterminate each other.  The game is based more on intrigue than combat.

You won't want to shy away from combat entirely though.  Speaking of combat, the tactical combat is a bullet hell game.  Which is ... atypical for a strategy game.  Don't worry though, this bullet hell is turn-based.  Which is a new one to me.

I don't think I'm doing a very good job of explaining what makes this good.  Having a chance to explore honestly novel gameplay for the first time in I don't know how long is part of it.  Plus it's, you know, fun.

review: Arcen games has forever earned my admiration with a variety of niche titles, and The Last Federation is no exception. TLF has you playing as an insidious space overlord trying to unify or conquer the solar system. Like most games by Arcen, it features balance mechanics centered around an overwhelming AI presence, or 8 AI's in this case. Rather than fight directly, you engage in a series of political machinations, sabotage, subterfuge and small scale battles to increasingly turn the tide of the larger conflict in your favor. It's great, it's cake, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971544967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1619927708}
review:
This is a very original game where you are the last of your very advanced kind, in a solar system of other races doing their own things.  The only game that I can think of that has a similar mechanic is Drox Operative but that is an action/RPG.  Your goal is to form a federation with the other races, which you do by helping, manipulating or hurting the other races.  Each race is different, with a different leadership structure and different attitudes.  The Burlast are very warlike, the Evuck are sneaky guys, etc.  The other races are basically playing a 4x game and will attack other races, form alliances, build up their planets, research technologies, etc.  You need to bend the races to your desires by intervening.

The gameplay consists of visiting planets and doing tasks (friendly or hostile) that will have various effects.  Friendly acts will gain influence with the ruling race and will usually gain you some credits or have other effects such as improving their planets, fleets or relations with other races.  Hostile acts will hurt the race in some way, destroying fleets, killing population, etc and will make the race like you less.  Some acts will lead to battles also, even friendly ones such as destroying a pirate base or removing spy satellites.  When that happens you will enter turn-based combat where you control your ship where you need to meet certain objectives (destroy bases, destroy capital ships, dock with a station, etc).  Your ship is loaded with different weapons and special abilities that can change over the course of a game.  Weapons have strengths and weaknesses against ship size, shields, etc and abilities can do things like launch fighters, destroy small ships around you or bring your shields back to full.  It's pretty fun but some larger battles can get a bit grindy as you are just one ship.  You often have help but I don't usually notice the allies doing anything that major though.

This game was really hard to for me to rate.  I enjoyed my time with it but after winning a game, I really had no desire to play it again.  It's hard to see that the game would play out much differently on each play through.  Sure you might have different allies and enemies, but you will still be destroying pirate bases, improving influence, helping build structures, etc like you did in previous games.  I guess I will give it a very minor recommendation because of the originality and my initial enjoyment of the game.  If you like the concept and you are okay with maybe only getting 10-15 hours worth of playtime out of it, then I would recommend it for you.  Just don't view this as your standard 4x game that you can play for hundreds of hours.

review:
[h1] Simple, But Okay [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

It did everything okay, not great, just okay.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

It was just okay.  It wasn't that deep of a game.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I wanted something with more meat on it, especially when it comes to space sims.  I really don't remember much about it, so it wasn't that memorable.  Again, just okay.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035212776', 'num_games_owned': 468, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1614808573}
review:
Underrated Gem of a game. You play as the last of a race of space hydras and your goal is to form a federation of the races your now-extinct race oppressed. And you can go about it any way you can.

You can outright commit genocide, go to war, convince others to go to war, bribe, scheme, connive and manipulate. There's a group of different races to contend with; from furry space communists, to Alien Hypercapitalists, It's been observed that no two games really are the same, and all the time i've played that's certainly been true for me.

I feel the game is strongest in the political/strategy aspect, I'm not a massive fan of the bullet hell combat sections, but they're few and far between, or you can largely skip it that it's pretty negligible. If you're looking for a novel experience, get this game.

There's also the DLC where you literally have to revive your fallen race on the corpses of the others, if you ever get bored of the main game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109756501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1667727727}
review:
This game is a really fun strategy game. The combat can be fun, if unforgiving, and you grow to like all of the races (usually at very different times). It's really well thought out and fun, though I have to say, it can be... kind of restrictive with what it allows. A lot of options can get locked out without you even realizing, or with little sense. I know that the Boarines are part of the UIS but how the hell am I supposed to make them leave it if I can't even plant false evidence of a conspiracy? How does it make sense that I can't do that, they have no clue it's me!

But aside from a few awkward decisions by the devs, for the most part it's an extremely solid space sim with tons of variations. I've beaten it three times already and I'm definitely not about to stop, especially with the extra game modes from the DLC!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010142117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1605565154}
review:
A unique space babysitting simulator that manages to scratch the 4X itch and pull off the ‘everything-but-the-kitchen-sink’ approach that a lot of space games are shooting for, but without collapsing under its own weight. 

I get the same initial giddy feeling I got playing Stellaris, except without the mountains of broken crap involved with playing Stellaris. This take on space 4X games is almost 100% focused on you trying to maintain a balance of power, and I love that. I say almost, because the game is a little hampered by (semi-optional) bland auto-generated space combat. But this space-nannying simulator still shines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037957937', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 13435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10988, 'last_played': 1706840466}
review:
This is a great simulation and good for anyone who likes to generate head canon or stories based off their gameplay. The game gives you a very simple framework of being the last member of a race who wants to create a federation that will unite the solar system. There are two major layers of strategy and tactical. Unlike many games I've played with that design, the strategy layer is "realtime" and the tactical layer is turn based. During the strategy layer, you're making decisions on how to help or hurt the races, choosing what battles to go into, or making deals with the planetary governments. In the tactical layer, you're adjusting your ship's shields, attack, and engine and pursuing an objective of some kind (whether that's to destroy enemy capital ships, defeat smugglers, or protect a trade convoy.) 

If you've ever wanted to be a giant space monster influencing solar system politics, this is your game. Even if you're not too hot on the space monster bit, it's not thrown in your face very much, so you can ignore it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11196, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1600254672}
review:
This is a 2D 4X/Grand Strategy space empire building game (but limited to one solar system).   Control a weird alien race that's bent on destroying all the other races inhabiting the solar system. There's a grand strategy component and a fleet combat component that's like a very micro-managey game of turn based asteroids... which is even less fun than it sounds.

Convoluted stats that don't mean much are plastered on everything.  There's 4K support but no interface scaling so the text is too small to read and the game is simply unplayable as a result. 

Very little effort was made to make the game digestible or enjoyable for players, it's just eyestrain, retro-pixel-tier low quality graphics, and unrewarding numbers on everything.  They're charging a completely insane $28.95 for this, twice the price of Stellaris when that's on sale, and it's barely 1% as good.  Just impossible to recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121570366', 'num_games_owned': 1589, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1406, 'last_played': 1670117137}
review:
It is a good game, an original concept (like in many Arcen company
games) and this is always very welcomed by me after playing numerous other similiar 
genre/climat games. You need to plan your strategy, in main game mode diplomacy 
is a key as you must help all (independent) space races to unite in alliance, 
all races are really much different so it is interesting goal, you are like a 
third side here and this is also unique. Events are there both random and 
planned by other races and you, everything is designed with some deep. Game 
looks very good, it has definitely very good music (really not expected this), 
everything is running very smooth. Often you need to take part in many quite 
similiar fight (like when fighting insurgents) which could be a "con" but they 
are very quick, enough so it is not bad. I can recommend. ps - Next time i will 
try on higher difficulties, espec. space fights seemed too easy to manage on my 
"normal" first playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005508732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 10060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8540, 'last_played': 1650752938}
review:
I love this game so much, I bought the Steam version for the cards and emotes.

This is my "relaxation game," where I can unwind from something hectic and action-oriented. Don't let that fool you into thinking the game isn't complicated. It's hard to describe (although the tutorial does a great job of explaining game mechanics) but you affect the societies of various races through direct actions and backroom deals to try to get as many of them into an allied Federation as possible. And, if all else fails, and an expansionist race gets too greedy, there's always the thrilling turn-based combat--eat electric death, alien scum!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027910053', 'num_games_owned': 1136, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 758, 'last_played': 1670880966}
review:
Vastly underrated space kindergarten simulator. Kids are vicious and cruel, and you are not exactly a good role model as well. And babysitting is the very definition of a thankless job.
What do you do here? Try to keep kids from killing each other, mainly. Killing you as well, if you're playing on hardcore mode. Kids have wants, kids have needs, and you want to keep them in line. Or maybe keep other kids from killing your favourites. Or, perhaps ward off a strange man on the premises that looks at kids suspiciously. Or start your own family with your own kids, while kicking the inhabitants out of the solar system.

People in reviews call it 4x game, and while it is technically true, this is a very unusual kind of 4x, since you're not the one doing those "exes" - it's the kids. It does give off a certain Majesty - fantasy kingdom sim vibe, except you are in a multiplayer game where heroes are put against each other. Well, and you are in space, of course, this much is obvious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006004915', 'num_games_owned': 1681, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 2118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1986, 'last_played': 1648464762}
review:
Both the strategic and the tactical sides are fairly simple, though it may take some time to learn which options are available when and how, but it's quite replayable anyway. Thanks to the two 'artifacts' shattering the status quo, and just general RNG and your own choices, the game generally won't go the same way from game to game. Maybe this time, the Thoraxians take over half the galaxy, or maybe the moon-throwers decide to actually throw some moons at someone other than the Hydra.
I really like that there are separate difficulty settings for strategic and battle difficulty. Not just because some players have different preferences, but because the games are so short that you can do a game with the strategic difficulty up but the battle difficulty down to see how chaotic it can get while remaining able to defeat the larger armies (though, I got the 'hard strategy' achievement with normal combat settings) or have everyone stay chill while you try out a much harder combat setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084004954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1606025968}
review:
Here is why you shouldn't buy it-- it's boring!

Why is it boring? It has a steep learning curve and little replay value. This means it is bad when you first get it, and bad when you learn how to do everything.

Steep learning curve? You are greeted with text walls explaining how you do things. There are so many things going on and the player must search to figure out what they are. Your ship gets 1 hit KO'ed if you don't know what you are doing (and they don't tell you, of course!)

Little replay value? The game is set as a short experience of founding a "Federation". There is only a few ways to do it, so once you do, there is little point to doing so again. And that's the whole game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981519088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1563825456}
review:
Catch on sale, interesting flavor of a 4x. As a heads up I have more time in this game than Steam states because I used the DRM-free install from Humble Store for a long time, works better on my older PC since it's slower. 

You are the last of a species called Hydrals. Basically giant hydra-esque dragon things. You were a sort of "rebel" that acted alone to help the other species your race was keeping down but then got captured and taken prisoner right before the Hydrals were wiped out in a genocide planned by a few of the enslaved species. The politics can be interesting, the races directly responsible for destroying your species could be destroyed and cut to the quick as revenge, or since you were rebelling against the oppressive system the Hydrals had set up you could end up allying with them. Peaceful religious critters, nerdy science aliens, furry warmongers, capitalist robots, there is variety but they tend to act mostly the same with each playthrough once you figure them out. 


There are bullet-hell style segments where you use a prototype ship and whatever ally fleets you can muster to do 2d top-down ship combat in space. Oddly this doesn't scratch my 4x itch in the 4x section of the game. It's just too different. Not bad, this is a very well made game. The graphics are not complex but effective and you will not be confused over what a smaller object is like some pixel-barf "retro" games do nowadays. If I want to scratch my 4x itch I will go to Space Empires 4+5 (sadly 5 runs sluggish in Win7 and up due to a rare DX9 issue after Vista) but if I want something along the lines of political intrigue in a 4x wrapper mixed with the ability to uplift or genocide species pending my mood towards them then this gets it. There is a bit of a power trip being the most powerful thing in the universe and deciding who to help or crush, hard to explain. Would be easier to tell you to watch some Let's Play vids of this game and you will see what I mean.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039811353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2642, 'last_played': 1710219308}
review:
Story:
There was a system in space with nine inhabited planets, each with their own race. One of these races, the Hydral, got spacefaring technology first and proceeded to prevent the others from doing so by shooting down all their manned space missions. The other races obviously began to conspire against them. One race ruined the Hydral homeworld through disease, environmental means, or both, and another race straps rockets onto a moon and destroyed the planet. You are the only remaining Hydral, and your goal (in the standard game mode) is to bring peace to the galaxy by forming a federation. You win when only your federation remains and you fly off into the unknown.
Gameplay:
Imagine a space grand strategy 4X game like Stellaris, except you don't lead any of the nations, you fly around pulling the stings in your favor. I should say the there are only three possibilities for what you are doing in terms of gameplay (besides deciding what to do next). Those are: turn-based bullet-hell 2D ship combat, waiting while you do a thing, wait while you do a thing and but looking at the map more carefully for activity. But there are a lot of possible "things" that your ship can be doing: influencing a race's attitude towards another, building up a planet's infrastructure, researching, sowing dissent, aiding planets, defending or attacking armadas, orbital bombing, harvesting space junk to earn credits to blow up a planet, et cetera. You will have to keep in mind all the consequences of your actions to succeed. Winning the game isn't easy, and winning the game with all of the races surviving really isn't easy.
My thoughts:
I like it a lot, however, I think the game requires a lot of patience and planning. Expect to go through multiple play-throughs to figure out all the mechanics. If all that sounds good to you then you should totally buy it when you can. RIP TotalBiscuit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036153954', 'num_games_owned': 620, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1564932146}
review:
The Last Federation is a sorta-but-not-really 4X game that is also sorta-but-not-really space action turn-based combat game with sorta-but-not-really sci-fi RPG mechanics.

Let me explain.

TLF pretends to be a 4X game with extremely deep diplomacy and subterfuge. But after playing a single playthrough of the game I have realized that it is basically even lesser than something like Master of Orion 2. maybe more akin to the first game to be entirely honest. Heck, even that would be a stretch, considering in that game you can colonize and straight-up build your own empire.

In TLF, you do not pick your race. Nope, that race is picked from you cause of story reasons. The only choice you have is which races you ally yourself or not.

Now, to get races to like you, you basically just throw money at them (which is extremely grindy to gain, may I inform you). Then, in order for other races to like each other, you just throw money at them as well.

Not like races liking each other actually matters because in my playthrough I have managed to get two races to basically be in love with each other and yet, for basically no reason, they declared war on each other anyway. These two races quite literally eat at the same table, listen to the same music, probably wear the same brand of clothes... and yet they are like "ya know what, lets burn all of that".

I love when the main feature of a game is absolutely broken. I have spent ten hours grinding money in really boring missions or basically looking at the screen as I felt my cells slowly die. Then I have finally thrown that money at the races to understand that maybe it would be better to be together against the big spooky robot people who for some reason have armies in billions where the rest of the galaxy has armies in maybe one billion.

But nah, war is it anyway. And you cannot even try to broker for peace cause of the races has a mechanic where their leader "does not feel like even listening to peace".

Oh boy, has nobody tested this? Not a single human hand has touched this game? Cause this seems like a pretty bad mechanic that surely has been reported (and yes it has been but devs and fans seems to just shrug and be like "oh yeah, works as intended").

Combat started pretty nicely, it is turn-based, you pick weapons, each weapon has different effect, you fight whatever is on the other side. Pretty solid ground I thought to myself. I have wondered just how much deeper is this system gonna go.

It does not go any deeper.

It stays the same for over 10 hours.

It never. At all. Changes.

So yeah, combat is sheit. The screen very quickly becomes busy with basically millions of bullets like I am playing some Bullet Hell game, but do not worry cause nothing in the game can really hurt you. Enemies have TONS of HP, but since you do as well, you usually win most encounters.

It makes me ask myself why is this even in the game and makes me understand why Master of Orion 2 was such a amazing game. Cause the devs actually put more than ten minutes into thinking about their combat.

The only good things about this game are the music and art style. Seriously, whoever made the music should be fished-out by a proper studio and work on a good project. Same with the art team. I am sure Paradox could give them a job.

Anyway, that is all. This game had potential but it turns into a rather terrible grind way too quickly where you basically just go from planet to planet, click one to two buttons and then watch as nothing actually matters cause the AI does not care about the values that you can affect. Buy Stellaris. It is much more worth your money. I would rate this game about 4/10. Maybe 3/10 without alcohol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068803494', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 2622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1824, 'last_played': 1657226008}
review:
这个游戏最大的特色就在于玩家不再是称霸一方的主要势力，而是变成了依靠各种手段在幕后掌控全局的npc。

默认的游戏目标就是让幸存的种族建立起星际联盟，但这并不是一件简单的事情，因为每个种族都有自己独特的政体机制和倾向性，稍不注意，强大的种族就会把弱小的种族消灭掉。

每个种族不同的政体也带来了不同的外交选项，有些种族可以主动干预其他种族之间的外交关系，有些种族可以直接干预其他种族的经济建设，想要让他们使用这些特权，就需要玩家与对应种族搞好关系，并花费信用点数来说服他们行动。并且，这些能力并不总是可用的，大部分都需要对应种族当前有对应的执政党派，如果急需使用某个能力而对应能力的执政党派落选，玩家就需要像想一些办法，让想要的党派能够上位。

科技在这个游戏里也是很重要的内容，一场战争的结果往往可以由一个关键的军事科技而发生两极反转，甚至连整个星系的外交局势都会因此而改变，所以在赠与科技时一定要慎重。我就曾经为了帮助一个弱小种族抵御入侵赠送了他们许多军事科技，结果战争局势马上就发生了转变，原本快要被屠杀殆尽的种族摇身一变成了贪婪的入侵者，顷刻之间就吞并了几个相邻的星球。

玩家也可以直接介入战斗，但是随着游戏的深入，玩家在战场上的作用会越来越有限，因此对于玩家来说更重要的依然是利用各种宏观调控来操纵全局。

这个游戏虽然年代久远，但是可以说是一款非常有深度且非常独特的游戏，每个种族的特点都做得相当精细，让人忍不住要顶着大段大段的英文继续探索游戏内容和玩法。

强烈推荐，这个游戏能够带来其他游戏都无法带来的独特游戏体验。

author: {'steamid': '76561198048011384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1619997572}
review:
I've had my eye on this game for a while now. Only bought it during sale because it had been 75% off in the past.

For my first game, I decided I would simply observe (there's an observer mode). I wanted to see what would happen without my intervention. Here's what I recall happening:

> First thing of note was that the communist space owls (the weakest race), had their homeworld right next to the ravenous hive mind (strongest race). Nature took its course and the poor hooters were devoured within two decades.
> Should be noted that the space owls, despite being the weakest race, are awfully good at making alliances with the "good guys". Without them, alliances would be more difficult.

> The warlusty Doom demons discovered space-flight and proceeded to raid all their neighbors. Their living standards weren't great so many demons defected to become pirates out in asteroid belts. 
> This only contributed to the raids.

> The solitary, territorial boar-people- in a stroke of sheer RNG luck- had their homeworld spawn in the corner of the map. They kept to themselves.
> Should be noted that these boars tend to ally with the war-like races more often than not. Since they were away from everyone else, they felt no need to ally. This was good for all the other races as they now had a fighting chance.

> The capitalist, morally-bankrupt robots were having a blast constructing outposts and shipyards. You might think they were gearing for war with the absurd number of outposts they built- until the war-orientated corporation was one-upped by the entertainment services. The alloy-smiths of the shipyards were consumed by the coldness of space as the robot residents threw a party.
> Should be noted that, unlike all the other races, every single citizen of these robots counts as a soldier (they can augment themselves at will). Their entire population can and will fight- there are no children or civilians. They also tend to ally with war-like races, etc etc.

> At this point, the hive mind and Doom demons were going to town, pillaging everything in sight. However, they weren't necessarily allied... or on good terms for that matter. The two slowly conquered the solar system over the course of 150~ years.

> In a complete surprise twist, the honory bill nye sciency aliens actually conquered the hive mind homeworld. Should be noted that this race isn't actually supposed to take other planets- they don't believe in that sort of thing because "honor". The game's narrator (your ship computer) even acknowledged this as a possible glitch in the system. 
> Pretty soon, these guys take over the Doom demons.
> And the capitalist robots too. All their outposts (now essentially entertainment complexes) are destroyed. 
> It would seems these honorable bill nyes made a complete heel turn with their honor code as they now own four planets (in all fairness, they only conquered the "evil" races).

> All the other remaining races are terrified that the bill nyes are too powerful.
> Bill nyes are too honorable to conquer the other races because the rest are "good". 
> Every race hates them while the bill nyes don't particularly seem them as enemies. 
> It's a standoff.

> Right when I was about to call it as a tie, the capitalist robots made a come-back.
> Despite losing all their planets, there were so many robot pirates in the fringes that they had formed their own pirate empire many decades beforehand. I had completely forgotten about them.
> They retake their homeworld.
> They pull a Planetary Annihilation and strap rockets to one of their local moons and collide it with the bill nye homeworld, explodifying it.

Honestly, that's a good place to cut it. All this happened without player intervention. The solar system is randomly generated, so no two games are quite the same.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196444306', 'num_games_owned': 1155, 'num_reviews': 438, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1657291574}
review:
This game has lots of numbers. The player can change the numbers, but the numbers don't affect anything.

I can help a civilization achieve a superb economy, but this economy does nothing. The citizens might get happier but happiness also does nothing. It will give me influence with that civilization, but influence is only good for changing other numbers (which also do nothing).

For example, the civilization with the great economy might become involved in a war with another race. Can they use their economy to build new weapons and win the war? No. They might have a medical crisis because they don't have enough doctors. Can they use their economy to train or recruit more doctors? No.

At least one sector of a planet seems to be in constant crisis. An environmental catastrophe may be ruining one race but they will make no attempt to fix it, they will wait for you to help them. This is either bad design or the world's stupidest AI.

Everything about this is illogical and confusing, and the spaceship mini-game is terrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341810436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1548502665}
review:
An incredibly unique game unlike any I have ever played, but with enough familiarity that it is easy enough to learn. This seems to be an Arcen speciality. It essentially allows you to play the rule of the ultra powerful Alien Illuminati, and pull the strings of multiple, VASTLY different civilizations across the solar system. You don't directly control a planet by default (the expansion gives the option), but instead you subtley influence the actions of every single planet... either for your gain, or their demise. Don't let the fact that this all takes place in a single solar system discourage you, as each species is fleshed out enough that it more than makes up for it vs many other games with seemingly endless, but monotonous universes. And the diplomacy system, as well as the actions you can take on each planet blows most space games out of the water.  Have the ultra technologically advanced civ dump toxic waste on an enemy planet to poison them? Sure. Aid in global conflicts, using your decked out ship to turn the tide of battle? A few clicks away. Collaborate on a joint research project, or fund an act of terrorism? Check. 

But this game isn't all numbers and graphs... glorious, glorious graphs. For space battles, it combines elements of bullet hell, turn-based, real time, and ability-based combat genres. With tons and tons of research/customization options. Something that on paper seems like a crazy combination, but put together works very well and changes up the gameplay nicely. Also, there are tons of endings depending on your actions, and scrolling my library, I just decided that I want to see at least one more of those play out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122394129', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 976, 'last_played': 1564548332}
review:
[b]7.5/10 - Great idea, good execution. [/b]

[b] Overview: [/b]
So this is a mix-bag of ideas that comes together and works rather well.

You start off as the last of your race with the most advanced space ship in the solar system. However, that won't last long!
 Each planet is working hard to increase their technology at a break-neck pace and it's up to you to decide how you want the events to unfold.

Essentially, you play as a manipulator behind the politics of this world.... solar system I guess would be the right term, with the end-goal being to create a federation that every surviving species becomes apart of. The game does not end until every remaining race is under your federation.

There is space combat and it's done in a unique turn-based mode so you can dodge any incoming attacks ahead of time and not get overwhelmed by the bullet hell. You need to upgrade your ship up to a certain point in order to stay ahead or even with the powerful races. Otherwise, you'll have to try and tell 1 planet to go to war with another and have them do your dirty work.

[b]Difficulty:[/b] (Above Average)
I beat the game on normal after 5 attempts which may be average to most players. The game does well or at least means well with trying to tell you how it works, but I feel it over-complicated the system. They block off certain actions that you can do until a certain trigger. I just go back and think, "ah well if I had the option to do that a few seconds ago!..." I'm glad they tried to teach you the game in parts, but with a game like this, it's just a lot of information overload to begin with. It's a safe tutorial that may or may not cost you a run just to learn how to play the game. You can always try playing on easy if you want to get the best grasp of the game, but normal was pretty rewarding to me even if I did lose or restart.  
So in short, don't get too attached to your first couple of runs. Use them to learn the game and hey if you pull a win out of it you're better than me!

[b] Oddity: [/b]
The only snag I have with the game is that I feel there could be more options to choose from in regards to what you can do and how you influence each race.

For example, without giving away too much, there are a set of races that can potentially create a federation of their own during mid-to-late game. The problem with this is that the game gives you 0 way to sabatoge that federation. In a game where the key concept is manipulating politics, I don't understand why this was left out. Whenever you do meddle negatively with a planet, you do get negative influence anyways, which means you would have to rebuild trust with that planet regardless. So why block that option out entirely? 

[b] Conclusion: [/b]
Aside from that, and I guess trying to over-think situations which I do a lot, this game is really solid. There are planets that you can manipulate rather easily, and there are others that will require a lot of work and you can decide whether you're gonna put up with everyone or destroy an entire race because they said "no!" . It's all up to you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043066997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 3839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3174, 'last_played': 1541289979}
review:
An unique take on strategy and politics. Here you are offered the role of the power behind the throne. You are the last member of your specie, destroyed during power struggles by other species. Your goal is to prevent more wars and destruction, so you go on a quest to unite the universe as a federation. Your only tools to achieve this are your powerful ship, the knowledge of your race (you can easily achieve scientifical superiority), shrewd diplomacy and ultimately crippling ennemies in a number of ways, either directly in battle or using shady ways.

There are many possibilities really and there's a fair share of randomness that will make it close to a sandbox game (in one game you might find that your favourite alien race starts in a strong position, in another it will start weak for exemple). Help some races to develop their planets and grow strong, convince powerful races to fight and exhaust themselves in a war so that they don't threaten the weak ones, suggest that a race straps rocket on a moon and throw it on the ennemy planet or throw toxic waste on the ennemy, share technologies to tip the balance the way you want, these are things you can do here. Each race is pretty unique and will be interacted with differently differently on how it is governed (if it's a democracy, a tribal system, a hive mind,...).

Overall the system is pretty deep, but there's quite an heavy random factor that will too heavily impact the game I'd say. It's a bit too easy to simply achieve your main objective to form a federation, but the hard part will be to make sure that all races survive and be part of your federation.

Combat isn't bad and you've got quite some leeway in how you can customize your ship and fight but it's a bit tedious at times, especially some battles barely feel like they can be won, even with massive technological superiority. On the plus side losing is never a game over, it only sets you back in your plans.

So overall I think it's a good game, not perfect but definately worth playing, there are many good ideas in here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1955, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1539789508}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

The Last Federation is a game developed and published by Arcen Games, LLC

This is a very different strategy game to others, and that makes it unique! 

Combat is asymmetric: the AI has a huge empire that's not focused on you and you start out really weak. With time you learn some new unit designs from the AI by conquering planets, but you always have to weigh aggression against attracting too much notice

There are a lot of different units so there are plenty of different strategies that you can emply. I'm really enjoying the parasite/leech ships, which will reclaim enemy ships after they have been killed

Turning the enemy's armies against their former friends is very satisfying! It's an older game with simple graphics, and the tutorial is excellent though a little wordy

The tutorial is a definite unless you want to be frustrated with quite a few unintuitive UI choices. Fortunately, it's a pretty quick tutorial, lasting no more than a half hour

Overall, this is a extremely deep game and I'm very happy with it. I think you'll enjoy it if you have a history with 4x/RTS game hybrids, especially if you got really into a few of them

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993971751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1420, 'last_played': 1431956803}
review:
I really don't know how to begin to describe this game. The only thing I really can say is that it's very unique and very awesome. it's got this weird mixture of simulating political tensions between different races and their war for control. Your basic goal is to influence this war from behind the scenes by pulling strings and trying to get on the winning side/trying to get your side to win.

It's also got actual semi-arcade-semi-turn-based-tactics combat, yeah I know that's kind of weird.

Actually a really good game, if for no other reason than that it's so unique. But aside from that, it's also a very good game that aside.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000167056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1683820147}
review:
Unite the galaxy, by force, persuasion, and underhanded tricks. But not by building an empire, no, you're going to be manipulating things behind the scenes as the Space Illuminati. A nudge here, a bribe there...

I love the concept behind this game and it's clearly a product of passion, but much of it is an exercise in tedium, unfortunately. Combat is repetitive and the learning curve is quite steep. Still, there's a lot to love in the Last Federation. Every race is different, has different politics, and requires a different approach. The races do not have symmetrical starts, so every game is going to feel fairly different.

My first game had me trying to go the nice route.... carefully inserting my influence into the governance of every race and slowly trying for galactic peace through the influencing Skylaxians... but then the Burlusts wiped all my friends out one by one, and I wasn't able to defeat their leader in a duel. Sadness.

Next game I started out with the Skylaxians as my enemy, so I thought I'd try the complete opposite and go for galactic conquest. I quickly made close friends with the Burlust leadership and united the Feudal bovines and the capitalist robots in a "Strong Federation". The rest of the galaxy was quick to form a counter-federation and after a liberal application of diplomatic sabotage and poison, we murdered everyone else in the galaxy.

I found it hard to love the game, but if you're looking for something completely novel and different, the Last Federation is it. I'll definitely be giving it some more playthroughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202173224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1692725920}
review:
An impressively deep political-social sim. Imagine a game like Civ or MOO, but where you're dropped into the midst of affairs rather than controlling a faction (although that is possible with DLC, it's definitely not the focus of the game). Distinctive factions, engaging mechanics and just enough humor to keep things from getting too serious combine to create a game that's like no other I've encountered.
It's technical, though, and the learning curve is steep. Still, if you're interested in a space politics simulator this is probably a good pick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080433284', 'num_games_owned': 273, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1608407634}
review:
This is a weird game. It is a really unlique take on space strategy, with many new ideas and other genres mixed in, but that still works.

It is really cool how you don't directly control any faction, but manipulate them by helping here, pushing here, pitching one against the other. So instead of building structures and training units like most strategy games, you have a somewhat complex simulation of each planet and its faction and you interfere through diplomacy, subterfuge or just by investing time/resources. You have a combat system that is a kind of turn-based bullet hell - you move your ship in complex paths and dodge projectiles and attack stuff. It isn't my favorite part of the game, but even if you don't particularly love the style it isn't obnoxious and doesn't get too much in the way. Very innovative, and I've seen plenty of worse tactical combat in strategy games.

I definitely recommend this for strategy games fans that want something new, there isn't anything quite like it. It is however a bit hard to learn, and not what I'd recommend for beginners in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050853525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7538, 'last_played': 1562065255}
review:
The Last Federation is a interesting and different take on the 4X genre. Rather than plan as an empire, you plan as a lone figure, with the aim of getting all of the different races into one galactic federation. 

Because you have little direct control, you need to work out how to nudge things to get the result you want, especially if playing with the aim of ensuring that all the different races are in the final federation. A lot of your time will be spent on 'dispatch' missions, while you watch galatic events around you, building up money and favour with particular races. 

The diplomacy of the game is the really interesting part, much more so that the combat. Different alliances can form depending on circumstances, not just the Federation the player wants, and as the interact with other races, races can become bitter enemies or firm friends. Overall, it's not a game for everybody, but if you are looking for a really different variant on the 4-X genre, I highly recommend it. 

Arcen is also amazing at keeping the game updated and doing bug fixes and balance changes as well, which I think really help the game. The DLCs are good - rather than giving aditional options or anything needed for the game, they offer new and different goals to work towards, and and are worth looking at if you want to get more from the game, but I can't quite give them the same enthusistic recommendation as the base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012363945', 'num_games_owned': 2121, 'num_reviews': 409, 'playtime_forever': 1041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1639040137}
review:
Remember the old saying "Beware what you wish, it might come true" ? 

This game is the epitome of that saying. Everything you do or decide not to do affects the outcome of the game universe in the weirdest possible way. The ways to manipulate things are many and it is just very hard to sometimes predict what the end result is. Usually things don't quite go as you wanted them.  

A most hard game too but that is to be expected from this marvelous developer that earlier gave us AI War which is also very much recommended for people who want complex games and a good challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005257426', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2217, 'last_played': 1506914322}
review:
I love this game. It's a little slow, conventionally. But as a manipulator who works from the shadows, I can appreciate scheming to bring the races together, through different tactics and strategies. It's really fun, the space combat is fun, the music for each race is great, and it gives a good sense of long time passing. And no matter what you do, your AI companion snarks at you constantly, which is amazing.

Also with the DLC you can become a evil tyrant and crush everyone under your draconic heel with a legion of killer robots. That's pretty fun too.

But most of all, this game has the best and most humorous ways to undermine and outright destroy planets - including one race's capability of igniting Gas Giant plants, and another's capability to launch moons as Planet Crackers. It's loads of fun too, even if everyone hates you for it. I don't think I've outright seen that capability in any other recent game to boot. Hence my write-in award "Best Weaponized Use of Orbital Moons",

I really appreciate Arcen Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028655071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1503734103}
review:
The concept of this game isn't bad. The graphics aren't bad. The sound track isn't bad. Where this game fails is a LACK OF PLAYER CHOICE, and issues with the combat mechanics.

What I mean by a lack of player choice is while many options are always presented in a sandbox-type open environment, the simulation mostly plays itself and the effects of you actions are unclear.

To win my first game after experimenting with various actions trying to see what I could do I figured out that the most important aspect toward forming the federation was getting the races to like each other. However, most of your actions don't impact this. You have an option to directly promote relations between two races but all that is displayed is a ticker of the influence gained each month. Click button and wait is not a game.

Slightly more interesting is you can suggest a race build certain buildings that have positive and negative influence gains, but there is no net gain under the current version. You sacrifice relations with one for gains with others.

For my first game I simply built hideaways on four of the races and set myself to help build armada for the federation. then 2x speed to the end and Yay! Victory with a federation of 4. Kind-of lame though to just 2x speed to the end.

The issue I have with the combat is some of the ships are too hard to hit. The just zip about and you don't seem to have a reasonable counter to this behavior because your targeting doesn't work well against this. Also, as the timeline progresses it appears the races ships invariably become ridiculously strong compared to your ship so the point of any tactical combat is suicide. That's a shame because the tactical combat was my favorite part of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062399793', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1502132330}
review:
This game has a very cool premise and some interesting ideas. I liked the writing style, but it doesn't really have anything like a story, so gameplay is the primary concern.

The big problem of Last Federation is that fighting everything is the fastest way to achieve pretty much any goal. And fighting, while fun at first, quickly gets very stale. There is no tactical depth to it - some cool ideas are there, but you will quickly figure out how to beat a battle (if it is even challenging) and then you need to do exactly the same thing every time this battle happens.
E.g. at some point you will have several pirate bases up, let's say 6. That means 6 absolutely identical combat missions to take them all out - and not doing it is simply the wrong move if you want to win the game (they give a bunch of everything you want).
If you don't put combat difficulty on maximum, fighting will be effortless and even more boring. If you do, you will just sometimes be bursted down and the already tedious battles will take ages.

If you don't fight, you will simply pick a "dispatch" (effect over time) and stare at the screen while the simulation runs. While the effort put into making a simulation with so many variables is admirable, all of that stuff becomes pretty irrelevant when, for example, one race randomly conquers another before you can react at all.

I cannot recommend a game that bored me after 13 hours that costs 12.6$ even here in Ukraine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032855540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1559027869}
review:
When you first try playing it, your initial reaction might be that the game is smarter than the player. At the end of the day though, the game is actually pretty straightforward, it's just very unique:

You are playing a roguelite game whose setting could be roughly understood as a 4X game. Imagine a game like stellaris or civilization being run automatically in the background while you play your roguelite spaceship game on top of it. The two bubbles mostly operate distinctly, you can only slightly effect the simulation that's running on the planets in the background.

Given this, the game has a bit of a learning curve just because it is not a goal that any other game I know of has in common. That said, after you get a feel for it, the game is pretty straightforward. The game is in some ways a bit spreadsheety, so part of what's overwhelming about picking it up is learning what numbers you should care about and how to make money in the first few years ("property development" and build buildings, focus on the "attitude" ones that let you sway how the races feel about each other).

Now, with that massive preface out of the way, the bottom line: The game's fun after you figure it out, and it isn't that hard. There are two difficulty settings, "combat" and "strategy", I played on Normal / Normal and won my second game without the dlc active. It honestly was pretty straightforward even with some flailing to figure it out towards the start, I beat most ship encounters without paying much attention to the power distribution mechanic (either max guns or some extra in engines), though it does work pretty well and I imagine would be very important on the higher combat difficulties.

I think a fair amount of the difficulty in the game stems from the number of possible victory conditions. Going for a perfect 8 man federation is going to be much more challenging than exterminating the solar system alongside one power species (though both are probably among the harder choices, for different reasons). I've only played two rounds and won by doing what I feel is probably the easiest choice: Piss off one of the two warmonger races and unite the galaxy destroying them, then crush the remaining evil hive race for refusing to assimilate. As far as the game is concerned this victory is no different from working to convince them both to join the federation, but it would've been much harder and I would have needed to play the game completely differently. (There are specific achievements for various victory conditions and alliances that can occur over the course of gameplay, for what it's worth).

For this reason, though I recommend the game and think it's a great example of a unique idea executed well, it definitely requires a certain mindset to play it. Only pick this game up if you're okay with an open-ended win condition. The difficulty (at least on Normal, this probably changes at the higher difficulties) means you will probably win somehow or another. It's more about the story of how you tried to get an alliance working before it fell apart due to a war, so you formed a different alliance instead to force a peace, or something akin to that. Or the alliance that formed without your planning and started to take over the galaxy before you could react. You have a plan and things go wrong and in the end you either have a galaxy under your control (in other races names) or not under your control (in other races names), the end is basically the same either way (because as I said, the background setting of the game is basically a game of Civilization or any other 4X... In the end someone gets one of the victory conditions whetherit's diplomacy or conquest). At the end of the game you're still just one person in a spaceship and your species is dead, so even though you "win" in the end, it's really the story of those other races and what happened to them.

I haven't played the DLC yet but so far I recommend the vanilla game for a fun game about being "the man behind the curtain" and pushing much more powerful empires around with careful nudges. If you want a game about fighting or winning wars, this is not the game for you. This is very much so a game about [i]influencing[/i] wars. Maybe through orbital bombing support killing 2 billion people over the course of 20 months while someone else does the real fighting, but that's about as extreme as it gets.

review:
Interesting, yet overlooked. I got this during the Humble Sale as an impulse buy because it looked like a "normal" 4x game, was a bit confused when I actually went through the description and didn't try until now. 

Basically the impression I get from an earlier look at this is that it's a combo of Diplomacy, various trading camees and of course 2D space combat games in one. People's reviews about it taking place during the AI's own space 4x game are pretty accurate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038439680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3579, 'last_played': 1702637464}
review:
An excellent game. Winning is extremely satisfying, takes careful planning and some hard moral decisions. That is, if you can get invested in the fate of beings represented by a few key numbers and some ships. It does require some imagination.

However, if you can, this game feeds the fantasy of being a superhero better than any superhero game I have ever played. You and you alone can save the entire solar system from the stupidity, greed and violence that threatens to consume it and deliver those who dwell it into an era of cooperation and peace.

8 exciting and diverse races and a lot of randomness in the generation of the solar system ensures that each game feels unique and exciting.

review: So im really torn here. I like it and it is a great and complicated game but it can also feel very easy and once you figure out some really broken mechanics it just is easy. Take for example the dlc betrayed hope. I bought it and played it and in 40 minutes (according to steam so probably less tbh) I beat it just by harvesting space junk then building 6 fleets and orbital bombing the hell out of everyone then I refunded it. The base game itself is a bit better but its still easy to abuse. At this point all i do is team up with the thoraxians and whoever else will team up with them and just boost the thoraxian economy and win. But once again I have to say learning it is fun so maybe get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027940392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 885, 'last_played': 1531050846}
review:
This is, in many ways, rather like dwarf fortress in space, though the learning curve is far easier and obviously it's far superior graphically.

If you're on the fence about this game, I'd say this: Even if you never really get into it and it never fully clicks with you, there is literally no other game like it, and playing it just once would be worth the price of admission. It isn't that I think it doesn't have replay value - it actually has an insane amount of replay value and is very deep indeed, it's just that for a lot of people that first wall of confusion about what to do next is going to stop them. If you push past that confusion and simply try to do things you'll learn the systems in the game, you'll learn it's actually very well balanced, and I'm confident you'll have a very good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034379048', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 672, 'last_played': 1527633922}
review:
A very well-put together game of war and politics. I've never been big on Grand Strategy games, but TLF does a good job of introducing the player to everything fairly gradually, and while the sheer depth and breadth of the simulation can be intimidating at first (my first game I often knew my larger goals, but was unsure about what smaller steps I could take to accomplish them) once you get the hang of things, the sheer amount of possibilites means that you could play the game a dozen times and have a totally unique experience each time. Both new and experienced players to the genre will find plenty to love in TLF.

In addition to a great game experience, the writing and dialogue has a charming levity to it, although the AI voice is a bit annoying at times.

The DLCs feature alternate gamemodes where your goal is to either exterminate every single race and run the solar system yourself, or protect the now-well-established Federation from an outside threat. Both are very different from the base game and provide a lot of new content to enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028146708', 'num_games_owned': 1667, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1562048333}
review:
The Last Federation is my favorite Arcen game. It's a combination of Drox Operative and SPAZ, except with far more complex and intricate mechanics. It's surprisingly approachable and accessible despite its depth and complexity, due in part to the excellent tutorial. (If only Paradox games had tutorials like this one, introducing concepts in a casual tone at a manageable pace...)

Like most other Arcen games, The Last Federation has myriad gameplay customization options to tweak your experience for the challenge you want. Separating combat and strategic difficulty is especially interesting; the game involves a great deal of combat, but if you don't like it much, turn down the difficulty and you can breeze through encounters to return to strategizing. The combat isn't the game's strongest aspect, but it's definitely an interesting tactical take on 2D space battles. Combat is simultaneous turn-based: you set your flight path, your weapon, and your firing mode, then you watch it take place in real time. It's similar to Frozen Synapse's turn model, except that there's a great deal more to do here. The real-time segments are the perfect length, and you can adjust their playback speed depending on how much you like Star Wars. There's a lot more complexity involved in making combat decisions, but those are the basics. You can customize your loadout (weapons and special abilities) when not in combat, adding strategic depth that requires planning: what kinds of ships will I be fighting? Lots of turrets/defenses? This complexity only grows as the game progresses and more options and possibilities open up to you, but it's never overwhelming.

The real meat of the game is the strategy you employ in creating a universal united Federation. This part of the game (all of it except the combat) takes place in real time with the option to pause at any time. Essentially, you're an independent agent in the middle of a 4X game and you have to influence the civilizations to achieve your goals. Unlike in Drox Operative, a conceptually very similar game, in The Last Federation you have significant power at your disposal. Drox Operative has you doing odd jobs for the warring civilizations, looking out only for yourself and helping or hindering the factions as it suits you. The Last Federation, however, centers diplomacy in the primary goal: you win by uniting all the surviving races. Everything you do is in order to accomplish that goal. How you do it, though, is the interesting part. You can affect nearly everything; from personally working to improve a planet's environment, to advising a race to mine their moons and brokering trade routes with the resulting resource surplus, to sabotaging a planet's infrastructure or aiding a ground invasion, you have great influence over every aspect of the 4X game playing out around you. This only scratches the surface of the intrigue and strategy involved in every playthrough. Carefully manage the balance of power, make sure the right races have the right allies (including yourself, of course), and hope no one gets too resentful of your noble quest for peace... or for supremacy.

I highly recommend The Last Federation to anyone who likes Drox Operative, SPAZ, any space 4X, or complex and replayable strategy games in general.
